head.title: 23 July 1708. – Extract of a Relation from Mr. Matveoff{{p0699}} His Czarish Majesty’s Ambassador dated in London the 23d of July 1708

note.bibl: NA Kew, Russia, no. SP 91-5, f. 136-137v. English translation.

div.p: Extract of a Relation from Mr. Matveoff{{p0699}} His Czarish Majesty’s Ambassador dated in London the 23d of July 1708

After I have received my Audience of Leave at Windsor on the 18th. Inst[ant]: from Her Majesty the Queen{{p0668}} with all gracious Expressions of favours for my Person and great assurances of friendship to His Czarish Majesty{{p0174}}, I return’d to London, and made preparations for my voyage to Holland according to your orders ; but having been oblig’d to contract some debts in the time my Bills of Exchange did not come on by the Hop of the posts, as soon as ever they arrived, I begun to account with my Creditors, had satisfied the most, as appears by their acquittances, and publickly fix’d the Term of the 22d. July for rekoning and paying the rest.

The 21st. Inst[ant]: I went out of my house between eight and nine in the Evening, to speak with the forreign Ministers, who usually meet together on Wednesday every week in Sommerset house, to communicate the news, they received by the posts, and converse one with an other ; but as I pass’d in my Coach throu the Street where the Duke of Boltons{{p1970}} house stands, I was violently and cruelly attack’d at that time of night by some persons,

who without giving me notice of any order, or telling me any reason stop’d my Coach, beat away my footmen, and then two forc’d themselves in to me, while the third set himself by my Coachman on the box, and drove away a fast as he could : They that were in the Coach took from my me my Sword, cane and hat and had the Confidence to affront and beat me inhumanely, so that I expected to be lost in this murderous attack, and therefore call’d out for help and assistance as loud as I could ; these Highwaymen continuing in the mean time to beat me, to hold me fast by my coat and pockets, till they ware quite torn, and to treat me barbarously beyond Expression : On my calling out, the people in Charls Street came together, stop’d my Coach, took me out of these vilains hands, and brought me in this ill Condition into a neighbouring Tavern, where these Highwaymen acquainting them that I was seized by order of the Sheriff for a debt of fifty pound, which I ow’d two Tradesmen for Laces etc: The people retir’d themselves and left me to the Disertion of these Robbers, who carried me with force out of the Tavern flung me into a Hackney Coach and brought me into a prison, where persons are used to be laid for great debts ; and had not a French Surgeon call’d La Fache{{p1968}},

whom I knew, been there to my good fortune, and set himself in the Coach with me these vilains the Baylyfs had either murderd me, or carryed me to some distant place, that their scandalous action might not be discover’d. As I had sent a person from the Tavern to the forreign Ministers, who, as mention’d ware assembled in Sommerset house to acquaint them with this unheard off affront, they immediately took it for a common cause, and the Envoy of Florence{{p2135}} with Mylord Lyffort came to me into the prison, whilst the Envoy of Portugal{{p1961}} with Mylord Feversham{{p1971}} went the same moment to the Secretary of State M[iste]r Boyle{{p1969}} to acquaint him with this violent proceeding ; but not finding him (thou they sought him up and down) they came back to me in the prison call’d black Reff ; whither his Secretary M[iste]r Walpoole{{p1511}} likewise came, and finding me arrested for such a small debt, and so affronted, contrary to the Law of Nations, he took a memorandum of it, promising that the Secretary of State{{p1969}} would come to me the next day, and make a very sharp inquiry into what had happen’d. Of all this cruell treatment the forreign Ministers themselves

were witness to their great astonishment, and stayd with me in the prison till two in the morning ; in which time having learnt the reason of my arrest, and finding no assistance from any one, I order’d the debt pretended from me to be immediately payd by advice of the forreign Ministers to free myself from this shamefull prison, from where the said Ministers and Lords being my particular friends carryed me home : Next morning all the forreign Ministers came to condole with me for this affront, the like where is to be found in no History, promisisng to engage in it as in the common cause etc: On which I immediately sent a memorial to the Secretary of State M[iste]r Boyle{{p1969}}, representing this violation of the Law of Nations, and the affront done to His Czarish Majesty{{p0174}} in my Person and Character, that it might be laid before Her Mejesty{{p0668}}, and a suitable redress obtain’d : The said Secretary of State{{p1969}} came himself to me in the Evening, expressing his great Concern at my misfortune and affront, and promising to obtain me due Satisfaction from Her Majesty{{p0668}} without delay, to whom I on the contrary declar’d that in case it did not follow immediately, and in such a manner as was proportionable to the greatness of the unparallel’d affront, I should be oblig’d to go away without receiving my recredentials : what will be the Issue of this business, I shall hereafter give you an account
